Style.name: CSS
Style.description: CSS is a styling language used to control the appearance and layout of web documents. It works alongside HTML to define how elements are presented on screens, paper, or other media.
capabilities: Modify colors, fonts, margins, borders, and other visual styles.
Define responsive layouts to adapt to various devices and screen sizes.
Create animations and transitions for enhanced visual interaction.
Control the positioning of elements using box models, flexbox, or grid.
Apply styles to specific elements using selectors like classes, IDs, or advanced combinations.
Customize the design of pseudo-elements and states like :hover, :before, and :after.
Use modern variables and functions for consistent and reusable styling.
Integrate advanced effects like shadows, gradients, and filters.

Style.name: Sass
Style.description: Sass is a CSS preprocessor that extends its capabilities, allowing you to write styles in a more structured, reusable, and efficient way. Once compiled, it generates standard CSS interpretable by browsers.
capabilities: Use variables to store reusable values like colors, sizes, or fonts.
Create nesting to structure styles more clearly and reflect the HTML hierarchy.
Define mixins to reuse code blocks with customizable parameters.
Utilize functions and operators to perform dynamic calculations (e.g., adjusting colors, sizes, or proportions).
Organize your code into multiple partial files and combine them into a single compiled CSS file.
Implement loops and conditionals to dynamically and repetitively generate styles.
Leverage inheritance with @extend to avoid duplicating similar styles.
Optimize the maintenance of large projects with a modular and scalable structure.

Style.name: Tailwind CSS
Style.description: Tailwind CSS is a utility-first CSS framework that enables building customizable and fast user interfaces using pre-defined classes. Instead of writing custom styles, you use classes to directly style HTML elements.
capabilities: Quickly design interfaces using pre-defined classes like bg-blue-500, text-center, or p-4.
Fully customize the design with a configuration file that supports extensions like colors, fonts, and sizes.
Easily implement responsive designs with classes like sm:, md:, lg:, and xl:.
Create reusable components by combining classes in your HTML or using tools like @apply in CSS files.
Apply conditional styling with modifiers such as hover:, focus:, or active: for interactive states.
Work efficiently with built-in mobile-first design.
Generate optimized CSS files by removing unused styles (tree-shaking) when building projects for production.
Integrate with modern frameworks like React, Vue, or Next.js to streamline development.
